CONCLUSION: No violation of Art. 6-1;No violation of P1-1
JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Christos Rozakis;Dean Spielmann;Elisabeth Steiner;Giorgio Malinverni;Khanlar Hajiyev;Sverre Erik Jebens
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in the town of GPE . She works as a deputy head of ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant asked the LOC police department to institute criminal proceedings against her former husband , PERSON . , complaining that he had assaulted her . She provided a police investigator with a certificate from ORG no . CARDINAL . According to that certificate , on DATE the applicant presented herself at the hospital , where she was examined and diagnosed with injuries to the soft tissues of the head . The certificate also stated that the applicant did not have concussion .
CARDINAL . DATE a forensic medical expert examined the applicant and issued a report which , in the relevant part , read as follows :

“ CARDINAL . On DATE of the examination , on DATE , [ the applicant ] has : CARDINAL bruises on the face , [ and ] an injury to the soft tissues on the left side of the parietal tuber . As it follows from medical documents , from DATE to DATE [ the applicant ] underwent treatment in the neurological department of ORG ; following her dismissal from the hospital she underwent outpatient treatment , consulting a therapist until DATE in respect of her diagnosis : “ concussion ” .

CARDINAL . The concussion , bruises on the face , the injury to the soft tissues of the head sustained by [ the applicant ] were caused by blunt firm objects and are considered to have caused “ minor health damage ” requiring treatment for CARDINAL ....
It can not be excluded that those injuries could have been caused in the period indicated by [ the applicant ] ” .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG instituted criminal proceedings , finding as follows :

“ On DATE [ the applicant ] applied to the LOC police department seeking institution of criminal proceedings against her husband , PERSON . , on the ground that he had injured her on DATE , at TIME , in their place of residence ...
I see particular social importance in the fact that the injuries were caused by a man to a woman who can not offer adequate resistance ” .
CARDINAL . On an unspecified date PERSON . was committed to stand trial before ORG of Tomsk .

CARDINAL . ORG held several hearings at which it heard the applicant , PERSON . and a number of witnesses and examined documentary evidence , including CARDINAL reports by forensic medical experts . The applicant insisted on her description of events as given to the police and prosecution authorities . PERSON . disputed the accusations , denying that he had even visited the applicant on DATE of the alleged assault . He claimed that he had visited his female friend , PERSON , on DATE and spent TIME at her house . PERSON confirmed PERSON . ’s statement in open court . The defendant ’s alibi was also corroborated by his son , who claimed that he had spent DATE with his father before the latter had gone to see PERSON witness testified to having heard the applicant and PERSON . arguing in the applicant ’s flat on DATE of the alleged assault . CARDINAL witnesses stated that they had seen the applicant in TIME the day of the alleged assault or on DATE . The applicant had complained to them that PERSON . had beaten her up . CARDINAL witness , the applicant ’s neighbour , stated that the applicant had unsuccessfully asked QUANTITY persons to lie in court about PERSON . assaulting her . ORG also heard a doctor who had examined the applicant immediately after the alleged assault . The doctor insisted that the applicant had not had concussion .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG found PERSON . guilty of assault and sentenced him to DATE of correctional labour . The sentence was suspended on probation . ORG also partly accepted the applicant ’s tort action against PERSON . and awarded her MONEY ( RUB ) in compensation for pecuniary damage and RUB CARDINAL in compensation for non - pecuniary damage .

CARDINAL . Mr PERSON . and his lawyer appealed , arguing that there was no evidence that the defendant had beaten the applicant . He had an alibi which had been confirmed by CARDINAL witnesses . However , no witnesses testified to seeing the defendant hitting the applicant . The witnesses also did not state that they had seen the defendant in the vicinity of the applicant ’s flat at the alleged time of the assault . Furthermore , the lawyer argued that the presiding judge had unlawfully dismissed his request to step down from the case as the applicant ’s lawyer had supervised the presiding judge ’s Ph.D. work .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG reduced the amount of compensation for non - pecuniary damage to RUB CARDINAL and upheld the remainder of the judgment , endorsing reasons given by ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE Mr PERSON . and his lawyer applied to the President of ORG , seeking institution of supervisory review proceedings . They once again insisted on the partiality of the presiding judge and the unavailability of evidence proving PERSON . ’s guilt .
CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the President of ORG lodged an application for a supervisory review of the judgment of DATE , as amended on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of ORG notified the applicant by letter that a hearing was scheduled for DATE at TIME The applicant was also invited to study the case file materials and to submit her observations in response to Mr PERSON . ’s and his lawyer ’s applications for a supervisory review . On DATE the applicant lodged her written arguments with the ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Presidium of ORG , relying on LAW , quashed the judgments of DATE and DATE and acquitted PERSON . The compensation claims were accordingly dismissed . The ORG held , inter alia , that the district and regional courts had not established what constituted the criminal conduct under the particular head of the criminal charge , whether it had in fact taken place and whether it had been committed by the former husband . The District and Regional courts , without proper assessment of evidence , presumed that the applicant ’s injuries had been caused by her former husband . Thus , PERSON . ’s guilt was not proven and the principle of presumption of innocence was violated .
CARDINAL . The applicant and her representative attended the supervisory review hearing and submitted their arguments . On DATE the applicant was served with a copy of the judgment of DATE .

CARDINAL . Section VI , LAW , of LAW ( in force at the material time ) allowed certain officials to challenge a judgment which had entered into force and have the case reviewed on points of law and procedure . The supervisory review procedure was to be distinguished from proceedings which review a case because of newly discovered facts .
CARDINAL . Pursuant to Article CARDINAL of the ORG , a judgment entered into force and was subject to execution as of DATE when the appeal ( cassation ) instance pronounced its judgment .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the ORG provided that the power to lodge an application for supervisory review could be exercised by ORG , the President and the Vice - President of ORG of GPE , in respect of any judgment other than those of the Presidium of ORG , and by the president of the regional courts in respect of any judgment of a regional or subordinate court . A party to criminal or civil proceedings could solicit the intervention of such officials for a review .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the ORG laid down a limitation period of DATE during which an application for supervisory review of an acquittal judgment could be brought . This period also applied to an application for supervisory review of a conviction , if such application sought a harsher punishment to be imposed . The period ran from the date when the judgment entered into force . In all other cases , there was no time - limit prescribed for lodging such applications .

CARDINAL . According to Articles CARDINAL , CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the ORG , the application for supervisory review was to be considered by the judicial board of the competent court which examined the case on the merits , not being bound by the scope and grounds of the application . The board could either dismiss the application and thus uphold the earlier judgment , or grant the application . In the latter case it had to decide whether to quash the judgment and terminate the criminal proceedings , to remit the case for a new investigation , or for a fresh court examination at any instance , to uphold a first - instance judgment reversed on appeal , or to modify and uphold any of the earlier judgments .

CARDINAL . According to LAW ORG , the relevant prosecutor was to participate in the supervisory review hearing . If necessary , the convicted person and his counsel could be summoned to the hearing to make submissions . If summoned to the hearing , the convicted person , the victim and their counsel were to have the opportunity to familiarise themselves with the application for supervisory review and written submissions in reply . At the hearing , the case was to be presented by a judge rapporteur , following which the parties , if present , were to be entitled to make oral submissions .

CARDINAL . Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the ORG identify grounds for quashing or amending earlier judgments . In particular , such judgments were to be quashed or modified if a court performing the supervisory review had found that the judgments were unlawful or groundless ; or if the pre - trial and judicial investigation had been CARDINAL - sided and inadequate ; or if the lower - instance courts had come to conclusions which did not correspond to the facts of the case ; or if the courts had violated criminal procedural law or had incorrectly applied criminal law ; or if the sentence did not correspond to the gravity of the crime and the character of the convicted person .
